displayed_text:
[Question]

Do you support the government provide basic health insurance for everyone?

answer.text_box: Yes. if and only the government was providing blanket coverage they address the inflated cost for the same care.  This would address the insurance companies inflated prices that trickle down to citizens.  If they don't plan on addressing it in this manner, we are all screwed as it will continue as is and American's health decline

displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: A strong majority support government-provided basic health insurance. A smaller share oppose it outright, and some offer conditional or partial support.
  • Reasons for support:
  • Healthcare seen as a basic human right that shouldn’t depend on income or employment.
  • Current US system is viewed as unaffordable, inequitable, and inefficient, leading to medical debt and delayed care.
  • Universal/basic coverage is believed to improve access to preventive and early treatment, reduce long-term costs, and yield better health outcomes.
  • Economic and societal benefits cited include protecting workers’ productivity, national competitiveness, and public health.
  • Many point to other developed countries (e.g., Canada, UK) as proof of feasibility; some suggest expanding Medicare as a foundation.
  • Desire to reduce the influence of for-profit insurers whose incentives may conflict with patient care.
  • Concerns and reasons for opposition:
  • Fears of higher taxes, government inefficiency, waste, and bureaucracy.
  • Worries about longer wait times and declines in quality or choice.
  • Objections to expanded government role and increased public dependency; preference for private-sector solutions.
  • Concerns about crowding out private insurance and fairness to those who pay more or work.
  • Conditional/qualified views:
  • Support if a public option exists alongside private plans to preserve choice.
  • Ensure timely access and maintain quality; avoid excessive monitoring or red tape.
  • Some want coverage limited to citizens or targeted to those who cannot afford private insurance.
  • Interest in including dental, vision, and mental health; emphasis on preventive care.
  • Support for a basic “floor” of coverage with the ability to buy supplemental insurance.
  • Lived experiences:
  • Several describe difficulty affording premiums, coping with medical debt, losing coverage after job loss, or navigating slow, complex enrollment processes.
  • Personal stories highlight unmet needs in mental health, dental, vision, and care for chronic conditions.

In sum, most commenters favor a government role in guaranteeing basic health coverage on moral, economic, and public health grounds, while skeptics focus on cost, efficiency, and quality. Many propose a hybrid model that ensures a universal baseline with options for private supplementation, clear standards for timely care, and streamlined administration.

Summary B

The majority of comments express strong support for the government providing basic health insurance for all citizens. Supporters argue that healthcare is a fundamental human right and a necessity, not a privilege, and that the current system disproportionately burdens low-income individuals and families. Many highlight the moral and ethical responsibility of the government to ensure access to healthcare for all, emphasizing that it is a duty to promote the safety, health, and well-being of its population. Some draw comparisons to other developed nations, noting that universal healthcare is both feasible and effective in many parts of the world.

Common concerns among supporters include the high cost of private insurance, the risk of medical debt and bankruptcy, and the inaccessibility of care for those without insurance. Preventative care is frequently cited as a key benefit of universal healthcare, as it can lead to better long-term health outcomes and reduce the overall burden on the healthcare system. Some also argue that universal healthcare is essential for economic stability and competitiveness, as a healthy workforce is more productive.

A smaller percentage of comments express opposition or reservations. Critics often point to concerns about government inefficiency, the potential for increased taxpayer burden, and the fear of reduced quality of care or longer wait times. Some oppose government-run systems in principle, preferring private options and individual choice. A few argue that healthcare should not be extended to non-citizens or that it should be limited to those who contribute through taxes or employment.

While some comments advocate for a public option alongside private insurance to maintain choice, others call for a complete overhaul of the system, favoring a single-payer or government-run model. A few suggest that affordable, not necessarily free, healthcare should be the goal. Overall, the sentiment is that the current system is broken and in need of reform, with a strong preference for government involvement in ensuring basic healthcare access for all.

Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: A strong majority support government-provided basic health insurance. A smaller share oppose it outright, and some offer conditional or partial support.
  • Reasons for support:
  • Healthcare seen as a basic human right that shouldn’t depend on income or employment.
  • Current US system is viewed as unaffordable, inequitable, and inefficient, leading to medical debt and delayed care.
  • Universal/basic coverage is believed to improve access to preventive and early treatment, reduce long-term costs, and yield better health outcomes.
  • Economic and societal benefits cited include protecting workers’ productivity, national competitiveness, and public health.
  • Many point to other developed countries (e.g., Canada, UK) as proof of feasibility; some suggest expanding Medicare as a foundation.
  • Desire to reduce the influence of for-profit insurers whose incentives may conflict with patient care.
  • Concerns and reasons for opposition:
  • Fears of higher taxes, government inefficiency, waste, and bureaucracy.
  • Worries about longer wait times and declines in quality or choice.
  • Objections to expanded government role and increased public dependency; preference for private-sector solutions.
  • Concerns about crowding out private insurance and fairness to those who pay more or work.
  • Conditional/qualified views:
  • Support if a public option exists alongside private plans to preserve choice.
  • Ensure timely access and maintain quality; avoid excessive monitoring or red tape.
  • Some want coverage limited to citizens or targeted to those who cannot afford private insurance.
  • Interest in including dental, vision, and mental health; emphasis on preventive care.
  • Support for a basic “floor” of coverage with the ability to buy supplemental insurance.
  • Lived experiences:
  • Several describe difficulty affording premiums, coping with medical debt, losing coverage after job loss, or navigating slow, complex enrollment processes.
  • Personal stories highlight unmet needs in mental health, dental, vision, and care for chronic conditions.

In sum, most commenters favor a government role in guaranteeing basic health coverage on moral, economic, and public health grounds, while skeptics focus on cost, efficiency, and quality. Many propose a hybrid model that ensures a universal baseline with options for private supplementation, clear standards for timely care, and streamlined administration.
